texts.definition: Parts of the game space that only a single player can manipulate directly.
markups: <style="Definition">Parts of the game space that only a single player can manipulate directly.</style>

Games can provide parts of their environment so that one player controls what happens there. This can make players feel that they have some security and have the possibility to themselves be in full control of what happens there, even if other players may be allow to visit or help with specific limited activities. Such areas of a game environment are called <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> since they belong to individual players and the effects of other players' actions are either non-existent or restricted.

Probably one of the oldest examples of <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> is <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Roulette">Roulette</link></style>. Here each player has his or her stash of chips that other players cannot affect - the only way it is changed is by the player placing bets or receiving winning from the facilitators of the game. The more modern card game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/No%20Thanks!">No Thanks!</link></style> can be viewed in the same way.

Although players can affect each other indirectly through which actions they choose to perform in the board game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style>, the specific resources in the colonies developed by each player can be affected by other players (the nearest to this is that resources sometimes must be discarded because other players have fill the capacity of the ships transporting those resources). The card game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> works on similar principles (unless using the optional military conquest rules from the expansion ''Rebel vs. Imperium'').

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ultima%20Online">Ultima Online</link></style> allows players to purchase houses which are <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> as long as their owners retain control of the keys to them.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mafia%20Wars">Mafia Wars</link></style> are examples of games with <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> on social media platforms. However, as part of supporting the social interaction on these platforms, they provide ways of offering presents to each other and helping each other out with chores including involving non-players. This does not void the <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> since each player still has complete, or near complete, control of his or her space.

Naturally, all <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> even if they allow input from other game instances, as <style="Link"><link="massively-single-player-online-games">Massively Single-Player Online Games</link></style> do. In fact, <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> with <style="Link"><link="asynchronous-gameplay">Asynchronous Gameplay</link></style> is a good starting point for creating <style="Link"><link="massively-single-player-online-games">Massively Single-Player Online Games</link></style>. In many cases, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style>, players can affect each other if they are agreed to this through becoming <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tutorial%20Neighbors">Tutorial Neighbors</link></style> are a special case of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style> that are <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> with <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> as players. By providing these, players can have access to one or a few other <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> without player <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style>.

For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> can either be temporary or permanent. The temporary ones can be created as permanent ones with <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> or simply be the result of players not being able to affect each other due to distances in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> (as is the case in most game instances in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>). These reason for temporary <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> is typically to provide a clear <style="Link"><link="startgame">Startgame</link></style> phase. The permanent type of <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> is essentially designed by providing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> for players depending on what part of the game space they are interacting with. <style="Link"><link="phasing">Phasing</link></style> is one way of achieving this in games with <style="Link"><link="mediated-gameplay">Mediated Gameplay</link></style>. However, the game space may or may not be an actual part of a <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game World</link></style> since it may also simply be a part of the game state. In its most extreme instantiation, as for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Roulette">Roulette</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style>, players have no ability to directly interact with other players game spaces and the card game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/No%20Thanks!">No Thanks!</link></style> shows how this can be combined with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style> about that game space. Less restrictive implementations allow <style="Link"><link="visits">Visits</link></style> during which other players can perform <style="Link"><link="altruistic-actions">Altruistic Actions</link></style>, or even allow <style="Link"><link="non-player-help">Non-Player Help</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> affect games with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> more than those with other types of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> since developments can accumulate, but can be partly countered by <style="Link"><link="visits">Visits</link></style>.

Even if all types of actions and activities are possible in <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> (which is quite evident from looking at the diversity of <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, all which have the pattern), they modulate <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> well since the safety provided lets players have a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>.

The combination of <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> and <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> can be problematic - in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style> each player is building the colony with the same name as the game and in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> one must assume an universal moral code stops military powers from taking over other players' defenseless planets.

For games with <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style>, the interfaces typically focus on these spaces. <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> may support <style="Link"><link="visits">Visits</link></style> to other players' <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> or provide <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> are a form of <style="Link"><link="territories">Territories</link></style> since players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of them. They are <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style> that allow <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> easily since they are initially <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> to all other players that have not been acknowledged as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Neighbors">Neighbors</link></style>. This typically support <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> well, and players do not need to worry about having to react to other players' actions. By the same reasons, <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> make it difficult to design <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> between players (but see the ''Rebels vs Imperium'' expansion of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style> for a limited example). Although <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> can still exist, games with <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> are less likely to have <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> than those that don't. Further, when <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> does exist, it is less likely to cause <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style> simply since <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> lessens the possible casual relations between players and thereby makes parallel planning between players more possible, something of particular interest to <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style>. Since <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> in this sense make it easier to spend time considering future actions, the pattern supports <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> in this fashion as well.

Although <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> are typically not seen as <style="Link"><link="instances">Instances</link></style>, they share characteristics in that <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> can be seen as <style="Link"><link="instances">Instances</link></style> for individual players. Other players may be allowed to enter these spaces but only have limited interaction with game elements there. Since players do not need to worry about other players, having <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> makes it easier to support <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style>. The last of these features also makes it easier feel a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> of when to engage in the games, making them more into <style="Link"><link="asynchronous-gameplay">Asynchronous Gameplay</link></style>. The same goes for <style="Link"><link="tick-based-games">Tick-Based Games</link></style> using <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> may be difficult for games using <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> since players cannot affect each other directly. Even so, <style="CurrentLink">Private Game Spaces</style> can easily be used together with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style>: either by having winning conditions based around <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> or by <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Game</link></style> aspects such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style> from comparing <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="high-score-lists">High-Score Lists</link></style>.
